summary.text_en: Marie Curie discovered radioactive elements radium and polonium, becoming the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only woman to win twice (Physics and Chemistry).
key_points_en: First woman to win Nobel Prize
Only woman to win Nobel Prize twice

story.text_en: Marie Curie and her husband processed tons of pitchblende in a crude shed, finally extracting 0.1 grams of radium. Working conditions were extremely harsh, but she never gave up. Her notebooks are still radioactive today! Sadly, long-term radiation exposure led to her death from leukemia.

fun_facts.text_en: Her daughter IrÃ¨ne also won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry! The Curie family won 5 Nobel Prizes total.
She used Nobel Prize money to buy 1 gram of radium for research, not to improve living conditions.
She named the element 'Polonium' after her homeland Poland.

experiment.description_en: In a cloud chamber you can see radiation tracks! Î±-particles leave thick short trails, Î²-particles leave thin winding trails. This makes invisible radiation visible.
experiment.why_en: Charged particles passing through supersaturated vapor cause condensation into droplets, forming visible tracks.

simple_explanation.text_en: Some elements glow and heat themselvesâ€”this is 'radioactivity'. Radium is such an element; its nucleus is unstable and emits rays. These rays can penetrate objects and treat cancer!

impact.text_en: Radioactivity discovery opened the atomic age, with important applications in medicine, energy, archaeology. Marie Curie's courage and persistence inspired countless women to pursue science.

influenced.contribution_en: Used radioactivity to study atomic structure
Radioactivity research led to nuclear fission discovery

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Marie Curie's radioactivity research opened the atomic age. Her work inspired Rutherford to discover the atomic nucleus, ultimately leading to nuclear fission discovery and nuclear energy applications. She was not only a great scientist but also a pioneer and role model for women scientists.
